title: 107_hr2550
content: The "Economic Revitalization Tax Act of 2001" is the short title of the Act. It involves amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, the Act addresses certain investments in United States property by qualified corporations. The "Economic Revitalization Tax Act of 2001" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and addresses investments in United States property by qualified corporations. Section 956 is amended to apply separately to qualified corporations with qualified income. A qualified corporation is a controlled foreign corporation in Puerto Rico or a US possession. The term 'qualified income' refers to income earned by a qualified corporation from sources outside the United States through active trade or business in Puerto Rico or a US possession, or from the sale of assets used in such business. The definition of 'possession of the United States' includes the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The subsection applies to taxable years of a qualified corporation after December 31, 2001, without an election under section 245(d). Section 951(a) is amended to reduce the amount determined for a qualified corporation by 90% of the amount under section 956(e). The subsection applies to taxable years of a qualified corporation after December 31, 2001, without an election under section 245(d). Section 951(a) is amended to reduce the amount determined for a qualified corporation by 90% of the amount under section 956(e) with respect to such corporation for the taxable year, or 90 percent of such corporation's cumulative qualified income reduced by amounts previously allowed as a deduction under section 245(d). In applying this section and section 956 to any taxable year, any amount not included in the gross income of a United States shareholder of a qualified corporation in a prior taxable year solely by reason of the application of this paragraph shall be treated as if it had been so included in the gross income. In prior taxable years, any amount not included in the gross income of a United States shareholder of a qualified corporation shall be treated as if it had been included. SEC. 3. DIVIDENDS RECEIVED DEDUCTION WITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN DISTRIBUTIONS BY QUALIFIED CORPORATIONS. Section 245 is amended to allow a deduction of 85% for dividends received by a domestic corporation from an electing qualified corporation. This deduction applies to dividends paid out of the earnings and profits that do not exceed the corporation's accumulated qualified income. Dividends are deemed to be made out of the most recently accumulated earnings and profits. The qualified corporation can make an election under this subsection at the prescribed time and manner by the Secretary. The election is effective for the taxable year beginning after December 31, 2001, and all succeeding years unless the corporation ceases to be qualified or revokes the election. If a qualified corporation revokes its election under this subsection, it cannot make a new election until the 5th taxable year after the termination, unless the Secretary allows it. Coordination with foreign tax credit principles may apply to dividends as per regulations. The provisions of sections 245(a)(8) and (9) apply to dividends described in paragraph (1) of this subsection. SEC. 4. SAFE HARBOR RULE FOR CERTAIN TRANSFERS OR LICENSES OF INTANGIBLE PROPERTY TO A QUALIFIED CORPORATION. Section 367 is amended to include a new subsection providing a safe harbor for transfers or licenses of intangible property to an electing qualified corporation. If certain conditions are met, the requirements of subsection (d)(2)(A)(ii) or section 482 will be considered satisfied for taxable purposes related to qualified income from the intangible property. The new subsection in Section 367 provides a safe harbor for transfers of intangible property to a qualified corporation. Qualified intangible property refers to intangible assets owned by a domestic corporation, developed or purchased by them, and used directly in active conduct. The new subsection in Section 367 offers a safe harbor for transferring intangible property to a qualified corporation. Intangible property must be used directly in the active conduct of a trade or business for which credits were allowed under specific sections for the taxable year. An election under this subsection must be made by the qualified corporation. The new subsection in Section 367 provides a safe harbor for transferring intangible property to a qualified corporation. The election must be made before the 15th day of the 3rd month following the close of the first taxable year after December 31, 2001. The election applies to the year made and subsequent years unless certain conditions are met. SEC. 5. Imputed interest and original issue discount not applicable to obligations issued to qualified corporations under section 956(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. Constructive dividends not treated as dividends for qualified corporations under sections 951(a)(4) and 956(e) of the Code. SEC. 6. Secretary to prescribe necessary regulations. SEC. 7. Effective date. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
